answers.body_markdown:
The issue is caused by this row:

```val networkPhoto = networkPhotos[Random().nextInt(networkPhotos.size - 1)]```

since you only have one photo in your `networkPhotos` list, the code calls `Random().nextInt(0)`. 

Looking at the `nextInt(int bound)` [documentation][1] you can see that zero is not a valid argument and for that reason, an `IllegalArgumentException` is thrown.

You should sanitize the argument before calling `nextInt`.


  [1]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/Random.html#nextInt-int-

answers.body_markdown:
The short answer: yes, the new tag "overwrites" the previous tag


The longer answer: tags work a bit similar to how tags work in Git; the tag references a specific version (a content-addressable digest) of an image, and can be updated to point to a different version.

When overwriting the tag, the old image itself isn't overwritten, but the tag is now pointing to the new version of the image you pushed. The old image can still be pulled (and run) if you reference it by its digest.

For example, when you pull the `busybox:latest` image, you see its digest printed after pulling:


```
docker pull busybox:latest

# 7c9d20b9b6cd: Pull complete 
# Digest: sha256:fe301db49df08c384001ed752dff6d52b4305a73a7f608f21528048e8a08b51e
# Status: Downloaded newer image for busybox:latest
# docker.io/library/busybox:latest
```

So instead of the above, you could also pull the image by _digest_:

```
docker pull busybox@sha256:fe301db49df08c384001ed752dff6d52b4305a73a7f608f21528048e8a08b51e

# sha256:fe301db49df08c384001ed752dff6d52b4305a73a7f608f21528048e8a08b51e: Pulling from library/busybox
# Digest: sha256:fe301db49df08c384001ed752dff6d52b4305a73a7f608f21528048e8a08b51e
# Status: Image is up to date for #busybox@sha256:fe301db49df08c384001ed752dff6d52b4305a73a7f608f21528048e8a08b51e
# docker.io/library/busybox@sha256:fe301db49df08c384001ed752dff6d52b4305a73a7f608f21528048e8a08b51e

```


While newer versions of the `busybox:latest` image may arrive on Docker Hub, you can still run the old versions if you know their digest;

```
docker run --rm busybox@sha256:fe301db49df08c384001ed752dff6d52b4305a73a7f608f21528048e8a08b51e echo 'hello from busybox'

# hello from busybox
```

answers.body_markdown:
A good idea would be to look at delegation. With this concept, your service could retrieve a new token that identifies itself as the user but with a special "act" claim that identifies the service. 
https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-oauth-token-exchange-16

Identity server does not have this be default anymore in version 4 but there are some examples out there on how to add it back in. This case would be pretty simple as you have said you can trust your service so all you really need is to tell IdentityServer that clientid is allowed to impersonate anyone
Here's an example https://www.daimto.com/identity-server-4-user-delegation/
answers.title: Access tokens for long-running tasks

items.body_markdown:
**The hypothesis is this**: 

A front-end app requests authentication using implicit flow and user is logged in. The app offers functionality for user to create a task/job that should perform a number of things at a scheduled point in the future and on users behalf. This might also be a long-running task spanning over hours (even days). The front-end app has its own client id (with implicit flow) while the service executing the scheduled task has a separate client id (and secret).

**Questions:** 

- What should the front-end app pass on to the scheduled task so the service executing the scheduled task can authenticate as the original user?

- Assuming that the task should operate with a refresh token so it can get fresh access tokens when needed, how can it get the refresh token in the first place? The front-end app cannot pass the first one as refresh tokens are not supported in implicit flow and it would be issued to the wrong client even if it had been supported.
items.title: Access tokens for long-running tasks

    cmd = New MySqlCommand("select testName from Testdetail where testid =" & Me.DataGridView1.Rows(i).Cells(2).Tag, Setting.cn)

        cmd = New MySqlCommand("select testName from Testdetail where testid =" & Me.DataGridView1.Rows(i).Cells(2).Tag, Setting.cn)
        Try
            cmd.Connection.Open()
            testNamebox.Text = cmd.ExecuteScalar()
        Catch ex As Exception

        Finally

        End Try

answers.body_markdown:
Partitioning is indeed performed by hashing the message key with the murmur2 hash algorithm and then calculating this modulo _number of partitions_.
This is done at write time by the producer sending the message to the broker, who then stores it in the log for that partition. If there is no key in the message then the producer does round-robin.
All of this is the default behavior, the partitioner is pluggable, so you could do anything you want for this.

This is also the reason why you cannot remove partitions in Kafka, as this would mean that data would need to be re-partitioned and then distributed to the other partitions, which has several issues:

 - the brokers don't how the producer selected the partition when the message was written
 - the messages are old by now and would need to be inserted at earlier spots in the broker's log, which is not possible due to Kafka's linearly rising offsets

Adding partitions by contrast is fairly simple, as this only affects new messages. Basically, when you add partitions the producers will after some time (metadata refresh when metadata.max.age.ms is reached) notice new partitions and simply include these in its partitioning scheme, whatever it may look like.

answers.body_markdown:
You can do it, but you need some script function, not just plain SQL.

Your objective from how the data is structured is to take the orders, and determine the box number. The ProductID = 1111 stands for "a new box" where to put the things of the order. Such as a package.

Fact is, you have to store a local variable to increase your value and by increasing it, you can then print it as output.

Your SQL CASE works, but doesn't provide the result you are expecting simply because it's conditioned to give "unit" in the corresponding row, like so:
[![ sets the box number as unit just if product id equals 1111][1]][1]

Just by adjusting it in this way, you would have, which gives back null just on the rows with `productid` equal `1111`:
```
(CASE productid WHEN 1111 THEN null ELSE 1 END) AS boxno
```
With the result:
[![ null printed as box no if product id equals 1111 ][2]][2]


But i guess it really depends on database you are using if there's some difference.

As test I created a simple table with the data provided in PostGreSQL, but the fact still stands as stated above.. you have no way to store a local variable unless you script it.

One work around you can use, is to use the `id` of the current row to determine which result you should consider, and stack it with a `count()`.

[![simple select with the result of the script inserted above][3]][3]


Again this has been achieved in PostGreSQL ( pgAdmin 4 ), by using this query:
```
SELECT ordercode,(CASE 
		WHEN productid = 1111 THEN null ELSE
		(SELECT count(productid) FROM test_stck WHERE productid = 1111 AND id < a.id)
	    END) AS,
		productcode,productname,unit,productid
FROM test_stck AS a
```
But you have to have a ID of the row you can access, otherwise you cannot make it. Also I didn't use it, but you should be ordering your ID list as you extract it. Otherwise you could have a different sorting which would lead to unwanted results.

Another subquery that might do the trick is this:
```
SELECT ordercode,(CASE 
		WHEN productid = 1111 THEN null ELSE
		(SELECT unit FROM test_stck WHERE productid = 1111 AND id < a.id ORDER BY unit DESC LIMIT 1)
	    END) AS boxno,
		productcode,productname,unit,productid
FROM test_stck AS a
```
The order by unit, implies you sort it, before extracting it. And the limit 1 ensures you select just the last element of the subquery, also the `id < a.id` is some sort of insurance.

Just to visualize the subquery complete set ( without the limit 1 ), it would be this and ordered like in this way:
[![enter image description here][4]][4]


I hope i didn't make it too difficult ))


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/SJ12S.png
  [2]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/qsGb7.png
  [3]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/xadC7.png
  [4]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/jp2u2.png

answers.body_markdown:
Your results seem to assume an ordering in the table.  SQL tables represent *unordered* sets.  You need a column to specify the ordering.

With such a column, you an do this using window functions and logic for the `case`:

    select t.*,
           (case when ProductId <> 1111
                 then count(*) filter (where ProductId = 1111) over (order by <ordering col>)
            end) as box_num
    from t;

This counts the number of 1111s up to each row.

EDIT:

In SQL Server, you would use `SUM(CASE)`:

    select t.*,
           (case when ProductId <> 1111
                 then sum(case when ProductId = 1111 then 1 else 0 end) over (order by <ordering col>)
            end) as box_num
    from t;

answers.body_markdown:
You can't. Period. An object which is actually defined with a `const` data type is immutable in C++ and *compilers know this and utilise this knowledge.*

You cannot hope to do that reliably. Even if you somehow manage to convince the bits in memory to actually change (using UB such as the cast you're trying), you can never be sure the compiler will issue load instructions from that memory instead of caching the load result or even hardcoding the value which the `const` object had at compile time.

Not to mention the fact that such an object (the `static const int`) can reside in a portion of memory for which your program does not have write access. Performing such an unsafe cast as you're trying would then crash your program with an access violation.

You will have to find a different way of achieving your actual goal.

answers.body_markdown:
I think the issue is on this part

> Control panel -> Domains -> DNS Servers ->
> 
> Name DNS Server: ec2-1-2-3-4.eu-west-1.compute.amazonaws.com IP:
> 1.2.3.4

The thing called `Public DNS: ec2-1-2-3-4.eu-west-1.compute.amazonaws.com` of EC2 is not meant to be the address of a DNS server

What you just did is that: You specify to arsys that : Please let ec2-1-2-3-4.eu-west-1.compute.amazonaws.com manage DNS for my domain which is not possible

Please remove that line and let arsys manage your DNS. Or better, use CloudFlare / CloudFront to manage your DNS

answers.body_markdown:
With the help of one of the members from raspberry pi forum the the problem has been solved.

**For the future references to someone like me**

    import RPi.GPIO as GPIO
    import time
    from time import sleep

    GPIO.setmode(GPIO.BCM)
    GPIO.setwarnings(False)

    GPIO.setup(21,GPIO.OUT) # direction
    GPIO.setup(20,GPIO.OUT) # step

    step_count = 72727  # number of step to run  change this to change where it stops
    delay = 0.001

    # drive motor clockwise number of steps set by step count
    GPIO.output(21, GPIO.HIGH)
        print (" Drive CW ", step_count ,"steps")
    for x in range(step_count):
        GPIO.output(20, GPIO.HIGH)
        sleep(delay)
        GPIO.output(20, GPIO.LOW)
        sleep(delay)
    
    # stop motor for 5 seconds    
    print (" Stop")
    sleep(5)
    input("Press Enter to continue...")
    # drive motor counter clockwise number of steps set by step count
    print (" Drive CCW ", step_count ,"steps")
    GPIO.output(21, GPIO.LOW)
    for x in range(step_count):
        GPIO.output(20, GPIO.HIGH)
        sleep(delay)
        GPIO.output(20, GPIO.LOW)
        sleep(delay)

    # end of program
    print (" End program")

    GPIO.cleanup()

step_count would change according to the calculations(depends on motor angle and the count of the distance moved for one revolution).

**Peace**
